items.message:
River levels are rising slowly on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon and Dauntsey Brook and stable on the Sherston Avon. Areas most at risk include the road at Reybridge.

The rain has mostly passed out of the area and rivers are expected to peak overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.  Further rain is forecast for Wednesday night which will cause river levels to rise again.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, or sooner if the situation changes.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.

Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

This message will be updated by tomorrow, 15/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.73 mAOD at 14:30 on 14/11/23 and 4.75 mAOD at 03:00 on 15/11/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 185 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 08:30 on 15/11/23, or as the situation changes.

This warning has now been removed due to conditions improving and levels dropping. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue if necessary. Further rain is forecast through today (Tuesday 14/11/2023) and levels are forecast to rise again this afternoon.

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse in response to recent rainfall.
Flooding is possible at riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade
The River Ouse is expected to peak in York tomorrow afternoon.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. 
Further rainfall is expected today.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
This message will be updated by 9am on 15/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Tuesday evening's tide at 23:45 on 14/11/2023 is forecast to be approximately 30cm lower than Tuesday morning’s tide. The total forecast tide is 5.91 metres Chart Datum (2.86 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Only minimal flood impacts are expected over high tide. Gale Force winds and large waves are forecast for Thursday, which is expected to increase the flood risk. We will re-issue this message on Wednesday in advance of Thursday morning’s high tide.

Tuesday morning's tide at 08:45 AM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with westerly force 6 winds and large waves.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Flooding is possible at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon between 08:45 AM and 11:00 AM on 14/11/2023.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.

Wind, wave and tide levels are now reducing. The lunchtime tide today at Portsmouth (11:38 on 14/11/2023) came in 3cm under forecast. Tide levels are now lowering and are not expected to cause any impacts for the rest of today (Tuesday 14/11/2023) or tomorrow (Wednesday 15/11/2023). On Thursday, further unsettled weather is forecast. While we may not issue Flood Alert messages, there may be some spray overtopping on the exposed south coast.

Wind, wave and tide levels are now reducing. The lunchtime tide today at Cowes (11:09 on 14/11/2023) came in 1cm under forecast. Tide levels are now lowering and are not expected to cause any impacts for the rest of today (Tuesday 14/11/2023) or tomorrow (Wednesday 15/11/2023). On Thursday, further unsettled weather is forecast. While we may not issue Flood Alert messages, there may be some spray overtopping on the exposed coast.

On Thursday, further unsettled weather is forecast. While we may not issue Flood Alert messages, there may be some spray overtopping on the exposed south coast.

Wind, wave and tide levels are now reducing. The lunchtime tide today at Southampton (11:03 and 13:20 on 14/11/2023) came in 1cm over forecast. Tide levels are now lowering and are not expected to cause any impacts for the rest of today (Tuesday 14/11/2023) or tomorrow (Wednesday 15/11/2023). On Thursday, further unsettled weather is forecast. While we may not issue Flood Alert messages, there may be some spray overtopping on the exposed south coast.

Flows in the River Itchen at Mansbridge remain high. 10mm of rainfall was recorded at Portswood over the last 12 hours. During low tide, the level around the White Swan Pub and Riverside Park may be able to fall slowly as the river can drain into the sea. The tide tonight (23:21 on 14/11/2023 and 01:41 on 15/11/2023) and tide tomorrow (11:40 on 15/11/2023 and 13:55 on 15/11/2023) are lower than the lunchtime tide today. The remainder of today and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry. We continue to monitor the forecast and will remove reported blockages from the river. We are continuing to manage the sea door at Woodmill to help lower water levels. We recommend closing the defence gates around the pub at least an hour before high tide. This message will be updated by 15:00 on 15/11/2023.

items.message:
A high tide of 4.75 mAOD is expected at Richmond at 3.00am on Wednesday 15th November. Due to high fluvial flows coming down the River Crane, the Crane Tidal Gates will not be able to close to hold back the incoming tide from the River Thames. As a result, the incoming tide will flow up the River Crane which, when combined with the fluvial flow already in the channel, will push levels very high. 

Some flooding of gardens and low lying land is expected around 3.00am, although we do not expect any flooding to buildings. Any flooding is likely to be of short duration covering the period around high tide.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.35 m and is gradually falling. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.87 m and is steady. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.

There is the chance of isolated and at times heavy showers through Tuesday and Wednesday 15/11/2023, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

We are pumping at Currymoor, Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations when river levels allow, with additional temporary pumps installed at Currymoor and Saltmoor. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away. Additional pumps are also at Elson's Clyce. 

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated before 1pm on 15/11/2023.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: As a result of a high spring tide and strong winds, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on the high tide this evening, 14/11/23. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present. The A417 at Maisemore is closed due to flooding. Low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.5m to 3.8m at 9:45pm and at Gloucester 3.3m to 3.6m at 9:45pm on Tuesday 14/11/23, no flooding is expected at other gauge locations. This mornings high tide peaks, Tuesday, 14/11/23 were at Sandhurst 3.45m and at Gloucester 3.44m. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message: Flows in the Lower River Itchen at Mansbridge are high. In the last 48 hours nearly 25mm of rain has been recorded at Portswood. Whilst not a large total, it follows weeks of prolonged wet weather. High tide at Southampton is forecast at 23:21. Tide levels are reasonably high, forecast at 4.83 mCD (2.09 mAOD) at Southampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, the river will come out of bank affecting the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Parts of Riverside Park will also be flooded. Rain has now cleared the area, and the remainder of today and tomorrow should be dry. To help lower water levels in the river, we have operated the sluices at Woodmill. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recommend closing the defence gates around the pub at least an hour before and after high tide. This Flood Warning will be updated by 15:00 15/11/2023.
This alert has now been removed due to conditions improving. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue if necessary.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue today, Tuesday 14th November.  Water levels remain high and may last for the next few days.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent rainfall that has fallen. The weather forecast is for some showers through today, Tuesday 14th November, some of which could be heavy at times.  Further showers are also possible on Wednesday, with the outlook remaining unsettled for the rest of the week.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar are high, following the rainfall over the last couple of days. 15mm of rainfall was recorded at Knighton in the last 12 hours. Levels at Alverstone have started to rise following the rainfall earlier today.  Levels are likely to continue to rise throughout the evening. Levels at Sandown are now stable, but will start to rise again later this evening or overnight in response to the rainfall earlier today. There is likely to be flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. The rest of today and tomorrow is forecast to be dry. Flooding will continue to affect low lying land in the coming days. We are operating Bembridge sluice so that water is able to flow out to sea between high tides. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Wednesday 15 November.

items.message:
This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Tuesday 14th November.  River levels are steady but remain higher than normal following the recent rainfall.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Diss, Eye, Harleston and Bungay.  The forecast is for some showers through today, Tuesday 14th November, some of which could be heavy at times.  Further showers are also possible on Wednesday, with the outlook remaining unsettled for the rest of the week.  Flood water is dangerous. 
 Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on the morning of Wednesday 15th November 2023, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and slowly falling in Alfriston but will rise again tonight in response to today's rainfall. In Hellingly, the Bull River is rising in response to Tuesday's rain. It will continue to rise this evening before starting to fall in the early hours on Wednesday. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, and gardens, and may approach properties in Alfriston. Wednesday is expected to remain dry. Bands of rain forecast on Thursday (9-16mm) and Saturday (6-11mm) could cause rivers to rise again. In Alfriston, the river could remain higher than normal all week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 15/11/2023.

Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.1m to 3.6m Thursday morning 16/11/23, Upper Pound Tewkesbury 3.3m to 3.6m Tuesday evening 14/11/23

items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and very slowly rising in response to today's rainfall. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, and land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Water will still affect fields near Shripney Lane, the A259, and also some areas of Durban Road. Following today's showers the Barnham Rife rose, reaching its peak at 16:00. The Barnham Rife is now falling and will continue to fall tonight and on Wednesday. Wednesday is expected to remain dry. However, rain forecast on Thursday (9-16mm) and Saturday (6-11mm) could cause both rivers to rise again. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 15/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 7.86 m and is gradually rising.
The drain level at HEPS is 7.88 m and is steady.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.
There is the chance of isolated and heavy showers through Tuesday and Wednesday, flooding remains possible over the next few days.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. We are pumping where possible at Huish Episcopi and other pumping stations in the Langport area. We are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to evacuate water.
Consider local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For water levels on the River Yeo please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed as tidal impacts have reduced.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land. 
We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

The Combe Haven in Bulverhythe is high, but now very slowly falling. The Combe Haven will rise with high tide around 23:00 14/11/2023. Peak level should be similar to Tuesday afternoon. At Crowhurst, the Powdermill Stream rose in response to today's rainfall, reaching its peak at 16:00 14/11/2023. The Powdermill Stream is expected to continue to fall tonight and on Wednesday. Flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe as well as low lying land and roads. Wednesday is expected to remain dry. Bands of rain forecast on Thursday (9-16mm) and Saturday (6-11mm) could cause the Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven to rise again. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 15/11/2023.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and very slowly rising in response to today's rainfall. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, and land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Water will still affect fields near Shripney Lane, the A259, and also some areas of Durban Road. River levels will remain high this evening and tonight before starting to slowly fall on Wednesday. Wednesday is expected to remain dry. However, rain forecast on Thursday (9-16mm) and Saturday (6-11mm) could lead to the Aldingbourne Rife rising by about 15cm. With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 15/11/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to the intense rainfall over the last few weeks, with the borehole at Kingston Russell rising to 115 metres overnight. The more westerly communities on the Chalk in Dorset, including those along the South Winterbourne Valley, Beaminster and Hooke will start to experience issues with septic tanks and roads may become flooded. Levels are expected to continue rising until at least the end of next week. You can monitor groundwater levels at the Kingston Russell borehole on the Check-for-Flooding.gov.uk website. Further heavy rainfall is expected in the middle of next week. Please avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can flood nearby properties and can seriously damage your engine. If there is no alternative please drive very slowly to minimise damage. If you have property flood resilience measures such as pumps, air brick covers or flood barriers, you should consider putting them in place now. This message will be updated on Monday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have risen at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. No rainfall is forecast today 11/11/23, but heavy rainfall is expected overnight on Sunday into Monday, with the weather becoming more settled later in the week.
Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham from 09:00 AM on 13/11/2023.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen above 99 metres at the Woodyates borehole, Levels are forecast to rise quite steeply for the next 48 hours at least. Flooding of minor roads is possible at this level. Some septic tanks are likely to fail with a continued rise in level. Areas most likely to be affected are the Vale of Allen, including Sixpenny Handley and the Chalke Valley. 
Householders with property level protection measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should put them in place now.
Motorists should avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage homes and car engines.
This message will be updated tomorrow, Monday

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at the nearby Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 116 metres above sea level.  Flooding to properties from groundwater in the South Winterbourne Valley is now expected. The Winterbourne will remain high for several days. Ensure that pumps are operational and that other precautions such as airbrick covers and flood boards are in place. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave will cause properties to flood. 
Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and at the beginning of next week which will keep levels high. A high pressure system may bring a brief respite from about the 15th; this may provide an opportunity to replenish any property level resilience measures.
This message will be updated on Tuesday.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

River levels on the Emm Brook have now fallen below the flood threshold, there will be scattered showers today 14/11/23 and tomorrow will be mainly dry. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is no longer expected.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert  if necessary.

River levels on the River Cut have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There will be some scattered showers today 14/11/23, and tomorrow will be mainly dry. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is no longer expected.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert  if necessary.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising slowly on the River Leach as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today 14/11/23, especially in the Lechlade area. Further showers are expected today 14/11/23 and we expect further unsettled weather over the coming week. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 15/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady on Bielby Beck as a result of Storm Debi. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near Bielby Beck, with low lying land expected to be most affected. Further rainfall is forecast intermittently throughout today. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 15/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bishop Monkton Beck at Bishop Monkton
items.message: This warning has now been removed due to conditions improving. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue if necessary.

The River Nidd at Kirk Hammerton flood warning remains in force. River levels are rising in response to recent rainfall and will remain high through today and tomorrow. The areas affected are riverside properties situated along the left-bank at Mill Lane, Kirk Hammerton. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. We will continue to monitor river levels. This message will be updated at 9am on 15/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but steady on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Todays forecast is for scattered showers, and tomorrow will be mostly dry, therefore levels should start to drop tomorrow. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow 15/11/23, or if the situation changes

items.description: River Ure at Aldwark Bridge to Cuddy Shaw
items.message:
The flood warning for the River Ure at Aldwark Bridge to Cuddy Shaw plantation has been issued. River levels in the lower River Ure have been rising due to recent rainfall. Areas affected are properties at Aldwark Bridge and at Thorpe Underwood in Cuddy Shaw. We expect the level at Aldwark Bridge to peak at a level of 4m tomorrow morning.

Please put your flood plan in place. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 15/11/2023, or as the situation changes.
